13.54.text:
Ian McMillan:– Here’s a poem about buying
burgers in New York:

15.87.text:
‘Okay gimme, okay gimme, two quarter-pounders,
two cheeseburgers, four side orders of french

20.54.text:
fries, two Coca Colas, two Dr Peppers, all
to go yeah, all to go. We’ve got to go.

24.45.text:
Over thirty-five million sold. Over thirty-five
million sold. Okay that will be nine dollars

29.50.text:
and fifty. Have a nice day. Have a nice day.
Have a nice day. Missing you already.’

51.84.text: I think the great thing is that children are

53.60.text:
so enthusiastic about writing. They get excited,
they get excited more easily than cynical

59.01.text:
grown ups. So I know that when we get these
young people in this room, we can excite them,

63.07.text:
we can get them thinking about their own writing.
What I want to happen, is that they see themselves

66.97.text:
as writers, they see themselves as performers,
so that they can look at a book, read a book

72.40.text:
and think ‘I am part of that continuum,
so that me coming to this place today and

76.55.text:
other days and writing about it means I am
actually a writer’ …. that’s the great

80.15.text:
excitement about it and hopefully they’ll
remember it for years to come.

82.81.text:
Paul Jenkins:– So the ‘Picture the Poet’
schools program has been running throughout

85.98.text:
the tour. It has run in Preston, Sunderland,
Lincoln and now it’s up here in Carlisle.

91.14.text:
Essentially, what we have been trying to do
is engage the children with the pictures as much

95.51.text:
as we possibly can, and from that get as much
as creative writing as we can out of the pupils.

101.03.text:
They have been doing lots of techniques in
order to be able to freewrite. There’s lots

105.65.text:
of ways that we’ve tried to educate teachers
in how they can bring poetry into curriculum.

129.56.text: Anna Smalley: Seeing the children interact

131.30.text:
and work in the Picture the Poet gallery space
is so inspiring for me as a practitioner.

135.90.text:
There is something about that gallery that
has a fantastic atmosphere and it really helps

140.15.text:
children calm down and focus; there’s something
quite special about that space. So having

145.64.text:
the children in every day doing these poetry
workshops has been a real privilege for us

150.13.text:
at Tullie House.
Nothing compares to seeing artworks in-person

153.21.text:
and up close. I think seeing the nuances in
the texture and colour and how the works are

158.10.text:
framed can be really inspiring for pupils.
Being able to take that back to the classroom

162.33.text:
can really fire them up when they’re doing
their writing, and is something that will

167.04.text:
stay with them for a long time.
Ian McMillan:– I always think that museums

169.78.text:
and galleries are the beating heart of any
town or city. To go round all these different

174.46.text:
galleries has been fantastic. In these hard
times, to see galleries still doing the best

179.56.text:
work they possibly can… The sound of children
in a gallery is a great thing, so to have

183.95.text:
a room like this, full of children, making
poems up is just what a gallery should be I think.
